title: A new way to look at data privacy
summary: MIT researchers have developed a technique called Probably Approximately Correct (PAC) Privacy, which allows machine-learning models to protect sensitive data while maintaining accuracy. The researchers created a privacy metric called PAC Privacy, which measures the difficulty for an adversary to reconstruct sensitive data after noise has been added. The algorithm automatically determines the optimal amount of noise to add to the model, guaranteeing privacy even if the adversary has infinite computing power. The technique does not require knowledge of the model's inner workings and can be used for different types of models and applications.
